The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamers leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects. PORT SAID.

Hotel Dragomans in Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.p: San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Express Motor Cars meet trains from Cairo at Sidi Gaber and Alexandria Stations. The Management have also arranged for the Motor Cars to meet all steamers.Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation. C. F. RAISIG. Manager.

div.head: TEWFIK PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: HALOUAN, near CAIRO

Formerly the favourite Residence of the H.H. the late Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.-- Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and cold baths attached to most rooms. House warmed by special system of Radiators adjoinging the Golf Link and Race Course, Tennis, Billards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling, dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate charges. div.p: The only First Class Hotel at Khartoum, prettily situatied in its extensive Palm Gardens on the Banks of teh Blue Nile, with commanding view from the terrace of the Hotel ove the Bluw and White Nile, Omdornian, and the Battlefields of Kerreb.
Entirely re-built. enlarged and refurbished in 1906; replete with all modern European comforts.
Electric Light, Stream Laundry, Lawn-Tennis, Stabling, Boating, own farm and Dairy products
Cosmopolitan Cuisine, European service.

div.head: MORTGAGES IN EGYPT.
div.p: DR. EID'S REPORT.
(*Third Notice)

Let us now turn to the second division of our subject, to the question of Bales on the instalment system, or ventes a e mes. In the last twenty years the old system of enromus holdings by the leading men of the country has broken down and the greater part of the soil is now in the hands of its actual cultivators, the fellaheen. One of the most important factors bringing about this eminently desirable state of affairs was the Domains and the Daira Sanieh. Of these the former was founded in 1879 to protect the creditors of Ismail for a debt of 8 1/2 millious contracted with Messrs. Rothschild, and its purpose was mainly effecteded by sales from time to time of parts of the property pledged. At first the sales were for cash, but from and after 1885 sales on the instalment system were sanctioned by the Government, that is to say, one-half was paid in cash and the rest by annual instalments with
* The first and second notice appeared on January 24 and 28 respectively.

interest at 5%, afterwards reduced to 41%. The superficial area of the property of the Domains was 494,837 feddans and by the 1st January, 1906, 290,804 feddans had been sold and had realised L.E. 6,397,882. of which L.E 4,512, 783 was paid up in cash and L.E. 2 029,694 remained due by yearly annuities : so that at that date, at a rough approximation, the Domains found themselves with one-third of the property in hand and only one quarter of their debt outstanding. And in achieving this result ventes a termes gradually established themselves as the most usual and convenient form of transaction and rose in amount in five years from L.E 80,000 to L E. 892,000.

The Daira Sanieh was started for a similar end as the Domains and after the Liquidation Convention of 1380 represented 304,708 feddans, guaranteeing a debt of L.E. 9,842,000. In October, 1905, the Daira Sanieh loan was paid off and its property transferred to an Egyptian company, 130,788 feddans having by that date been sold and having realised L.E. 890,965, the usual terms of sale being 1/16 in cash and the rest by 15 yearly instalments with interest at 5 %, or 20 yearly instalments with interest at 5 1/2%. The remainder of the property was realized. by the new company on somewhat similar terms and on the 1st January, 1906, of the 16 1/2 millions which formed the sale price 81/4 millions remained owing on instalments.

The example of these public institutions was shortly followed by private enterprises of a similar nature, among the most notable if which may be ranked the Bebera Company, the Abonkir Company, the Societe Agricole et Idustrielle de Egypte, the Societe Fonciere d'Egypt, and the Compagnie Immobiliere d'Egypte. These, together with such of the numerous recent growths as have existed for sufficient time to possess a balance sheet, show a return of ventes a terme amounting to a total sum of L.E. 10,752,720. The grand total, therefore, en resume, of the mortgage debt in 1906 may now be established at L.E. 38,997,720, comprised of the following items : £20,600,000 mortgages to the banks, L.E. 7,645,000 mortgages to individuals and private companies and L.E. 10,752,720 moneys due on land sold by instalments.

Coming now in due course to the history of the mortgage debt of the country : it is only natural this cannot be carried very far back— so far at least as it requires the support of figures--- when we reflect that registration of mortgages was coincident with the foundation of the Mixed Tribunals in 1876 and the first researches of any import were not made until 1894, when the Legislative Connoil pronounced the total amount of the then existing mortgage debt to be L.B. 20,000,000. However, Sir Elwin Palmer, the Financial Adviser of the time, in examining into this figure promptly reduced it to LE. 7,323,300, showing many major errors in the system adopted by the Legislative Council in attaining its figure, errors which at times even went so far as to reckon the same debt three times over since it was registered in three tribunals.

In the following year Sir Elwin Palmer issed his own report, which stated that of a total area of 4,721,300 feddans 395,600 feddans were under mortgage, or, putting it in another way, that out of a total value of L.E. 120,000,000 mortgages had been raised up to L.E.7,323,300 making the average mortgage indebtedness in 1895 6.16%. But this figure Dr. Eid considers an under-statement as omitting to take into consideration the mortgages “chirographires”, which in that golden age of petty usury must have amounted to no inconsiderable sum. He would therefore raise the 6.16% of Sir Elwin to 9 %. This calculation of course only concerns the agricultural debt, and it must not be forgotten that since that date the population has risen from 8 to 11 million, the area of cultivation from 4 1/2 o 5 1/2 millions ot feddans, and their value from L.E. 120,000,000 to L.E. 350,000,000. Further, ot the L.E. 39,000,000 already established as the present amount of the mortgage debt of Egypt to-day at least one fifth of that is represented by town property, do that to make a comparison on even terms with the figures of 1895 we must deduct L.E. 7,800,000 from our L.E 39,000,000, leaving £31,200,000 as the agricultural debt on a property worth 350 millions, bringing the mean percentage to 8.9 %. So that even if we accept Sir Elwin Palmer’s figure of 6.16 % for 1895 the average or percentage of the mortgage stands at much the same figure to-day as it stood eleven years ago.

div.head: A Paternal Government.
div.p: The Sudan Government is laborating a law relative to non-Mussulman marriages, and also a law for public health.

div.head: The Brindsl Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port-Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O, Alexandira, a 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.

div.head: Lots Turcs.
div.p: The "gos lot" a yesterday's drawing of Ottoman Railway Lottery bonds was won by the holder of bond No. 1,555,793

div.head: Arrival of Tourists.
div.p: The White Star liner Canopic arrived at Alexandria this morning from New York with a large number of tourists on board.

div.head: Cairo Station.
div.p: Habib Bey Salama, station-master at Cairo, has been appointed inspector under the Railway Administration. He will be succeeded by Safwat Effendi, late station-mater at Zagazig.

div.head: Al Azhar.
div.p: Sheikh Hassouna el Nawai made his official entry to Al Azhar on Wednesday. The venerable sheikh was received by the professors and students with dignified and imposing ceremony.

div.head: Cairo Tramway Company.
div.p: The Cairo Tramway Compnay has decided to run motor-omnibues in streets which are not served by its lines. The company proposes putting the bases in circulation towards the end of the current month.

div.head: Sudden Death.
div.p: M. Cleanthes Photios, a Greek merchant of Alexandira, who was staying at the Hotel St. Petersburg, died yesterday, immediately after dinner, from an apoplectic stroke. He was aged seventy and was in the best of health.

div.head: British Club, Alexandira.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the members of the British Club will be held at the club on Saturday, 2nd inst, at 9 p.m. Business: To pass accounts for 1906. To elect general Committee for 1907. To comfirm rules, subject to modifications. General.

div.head: Bank of Egypt.
div.p: The directors have decided to recommend a dividend of 10 per cent. for the year dended december 31, 1906, of which an interim dividend of 4 per cent. was paid in July; also a bounus of 20s. per share, together with 18 per cent. for the year, leaving 15,357 (after adding 40,000 to the reserve) to be carried foward.

div.head: Boy Attempts Suicide.
div.p: A pupil of the Tewfikieh School, Cairo Ahmed Hamdi, recently attempted to commit suicide by swallowing ammonia. He was barely saved from the suffocation and removed to the Voronoff Hospital. Metal distress following a painfull illness is believed to have inspired his attempt to take his own life.

div.head: British Recreation Club, Cairo.
div.p: The final arrangements for the smoking concert to be held at the British Recreation Club to morrow have now been completed, and there is ample justification for the sanguine anticipations of the entertainments committtee that this partiular concert will prove a record in every respect in the annals of the club. A splendidly arragned programme of songs, comic and sentimental, pianoforte selections, violin and piccolo solos, etc, will be submitted during the evening, and interesting features which deserve more that passing mention are a sword dance and Highland fling to bagpipe music and a skirt dance by a dancer of more than ordinary repure. Althogether, the entertainment is likely to lack nothing either in variet, interest, or sustained appreciation, and members and their friends will do well to turn up early. The concert commences at 9 p.m. prompt.

div.head: Health and Comfort for All.
div.p: It is with pleasure that we inform our readers that a long felt want fo rapidly heating a bath without trouble and expense has finally been solved by a newly invented rapid water heater specially made for use where gas does not exist. It can be heated with wood, charcoal, coke, hadan, or any kind of fuel, and produces a hot bath (5ft. 6in.) in eigth minutes. It is small in size, easily installed, and specially recommended for rented houses. the price is only P.T. 8000, including installation expenses in Alexandria and suburbs, or packing and delivery free of any part of Egypt. If desired the amount may be payable in instalments of 100 P.T. per month. Further particulars may be obtained from Messrs. Moros & Cotsos, Boulevard Ramleh No. 15, Alexandria, the sole agents for Egypt and the Sudan. 29467-2-1

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN MAILS.
div.p: COMPLAINTS IN ENGLAND
The following, which we extract from our London contemporary the "Daily Mirror,” will be read with interest here -
Widespread endorsement is given to the complaint voiced in the "Daily Mirror" yesterday, of the irregular way in which the English traveller receives his letters while in Egypt

"The truth is,” the "Daily Mirror" was told at the London offices of the "Egyptian Gazette,” "chat instead of there being four regular mails a week from London to Egypt, as the ‘Post Office Guide’ states, there are really only two that count and may be relied upon the P and O. and the Austrian Lloyd.

"But people here seem to forget about the Austrian Lloyd's mail on Tuesdays, and send all letters by the P and O. on Fridays, with the result that English folk in Egypt find that the latter is practically their only mail.
"From Egypt to England the mails are ever so much better and more regular. What we want is at least two good outward mails a week that we oan depend on."

The agents for the Austrian Lloyd Steam Navigation Company told the "Daily Mirror" that their boats leave Brindisi every Friday, the moment they receive the mails marked, "Per Austrian Packet," and there is never any delay on their part, because they are bound, under heavy penalties, to run to schedale time from Trieste and Brindisi to Alexandria.
"We blame the English Post Office," they said. "Because what happens is this : If a letter is not marked by any special line the Post Office can do what it likes with it."

"Of course, they ought: to send a letter by the very next mail, but, apparently, they don't trouble unless it is marked. They study this matter more thoroughly in Egypt, and that is why the dispatch from Egypt to England is so much better than the other way about."

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: A propos of the Khedive’s trip to Siwa. it is interesting to learn from "Al Ahram" that on the occasion of his last visit to the oasis his Highness took with him a number of varieties of seeds, which he presented to the inhabitants, whom he also showed how to use agricultural implements, how to irrigate their lands by means of fountains, and how to graft palm trees. His Highness is accompanied on his present visit by a number of engineers and agriculturists belonging to the Khasa.

div.head: THE SOLLUM AFFAIR.
div.p: According to the "Politische Korrespondenz" the Khedive is not willing to protest against the construction of fortifications by the Ottoman troops on the Egyptian-Tripolitan fronter. The same organ declates that Lord Cromer desires to raise the question.

div.head: BULGARIA AND EGYPT.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary reports that the difficulty touching the appointment of a Bulgarian Diplomatic Agent at Cairo has been settled by a concession on the part of the Grand Vizier. M. Vernezza, however, will not be a Diplomatic,but a Commercial Agent.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: "A1 Watan" says: The question of the Capitulations will be the most important that Lord Cromer and the Press will have to consider. This is a Gordian knit which must be cut in some way or another. If the Powers ratify Lord Cromer's proposals, England will have a deciding voice, and certain persons who are opposed to Lord Cromer's views have therefore suggested the idea of enlarging the circle of the jurisdiction of the Mixed Carts and investing them with penal jurisdiction over foreigners..... While we do not deny that the realisation of this idea would lessen British power in Egypt, we do not see on the other hand how Egypt is to gain by reason of the continuance of internationalism and the diminution of British power. England hears a very high reputation for justice and sense, and the foot that she was made ths depositary of the powers of other nations could do Egypt no harm, and might indeed be beneficial to our country as it would tend to lighten the yoke of the Capitulations, and reduce the criminality prevalent among certain foreign elements.

div.head: CAIRO STREET DANGERS.
div.p: A lady visitor to Cairo writes : —In the course of ten deys 1 have personally noted four collisions between carriages and motors at the corner of the Hotel d'Angleterre. It happens to be situated at the junction of four busy streets. It is common knowledge that arabeyahs in this city are driven at a reckless speed and with intolerable slackness and carelessness. We have now the added terror of motors propelled with the traditional "dash," and as there is a heavy increase of traffic it is high time the latter was more efficiently policed. The last and most serions accident at the aforementioned corner I prophesised was bound to ocour. The motor buses as a general rule are turned into the Sharia Magrabi on the wrong side of the road at a speed of 12 to 16 miles an hour. It was surprising in the inevitable debacle that the heavy vehicle left as much of the arabeyah intact as was the case.

There was the usual painful exit of injured passengers to the chemist's shop, which providentially abuts on the road at this spot. We are in urgent need of amounted policeman at this dangerous corner to direct and control the traffic, especially during the busy hours. I would suggest that a member of our fine body of police should also be on duty there at night

div.head: COLD AT CYPRUS.
div.p: ARTIC WEATHER
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Larnacs, 24th January.

Not for many years past has Cyprus experienoed such cold weather as that which has prevailed for the last week. Snow covers the Troodos range, as is usnal at this season, but it also powders the Northern or Kyrenia mountains, and a slight fall was recorded in Nicosia itself on the 22nd instant.

The north and north-westerly winds blowing icily across from the snow-clad Karamanian heights, renew their edge as they pass over the Kyrenia hills before dropping down into the plain. It is, therefore, not surprising that the inhabitants of our motropolis are at one in describing the climatic conditions there as being almost Arctic. Very few houses in Cyprus are designed for such weather, and a change to milder conditions is hoped for. For some days the "bazaar" in Nicosia has been partially closed, as tradesmen have absented themselves from the leaky, draughty, wooden structures which, for the most part, form their places of business, and, doubtless, trade has to some extent saffared in consequence.

It is announced that, under the auspices of the Committee for the Improvement of Cyprus Stock, the usual show of horses, donkeys, bulls, cows, and rams, will be held at Nicosia on the 3rd day of Kourban- Beyram.

Mr. Lewis Biddolph, brother of Lady King- Harman, who is coming to Cyprau to be married, is expected to arrive from Cairo by this mail. His father, General Sir Robert Biddolph, is also due to reach Cyprus at the same time from England, accompanied by one of his daughters.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AFFAIR
div.p: The authorities of the Alexandira Gouvernorat will not terminate the enquiry into the assault on the police by the mob in the outrage at the Russian Consulate befroe the end of the next week.
A subscription has been opened at Cairo for the families of the Russians, and P.T. 1,782.5 has been collected.

div.head: DISORDERS AT JERUSALEM.
div.p: Advices from the Holy City report another scandalous disturbance between militant and rival ecclesiastics. The Gregorian Armenians abjected to interference on the part of Latin clergy in the celebration of their liturgy in the Holy Sepulchre, and a scene ensued in the course of which violence was employed.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS.
div.p: We are authorized to state that the report which appeared recently to the effect that a concession had been granted by the Government to the company giving them a monopoly as regards the sale of nitrates is incorrect. The company have the intentions to take up the nitrate business, and for this purpose further capital will be issued on the terms already made public.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "Zaza," we feel assured, must represent the final low water-mark at opera. Horace's “difficile est proprie communia dicere" applies with tenfold force when the communia have to be passionately intoned before a crowded house. It is diffiiult enough, as Wagner has observed, to tolerate long musical dia- logues, even when they abound in noble and exalted sentiment ; what, then, are we to think of such a recitative (comme valeur ésthétique) as the following : —

Michelin. “Augosto ! Augusto !” (running to the table). "Pronti !" Michelin. “One beer:" to Claretta, "What’s yours ?" (e voi, su, che piendete?). Claretta. "A kammel, thanks.” Courtois. "A big glass for me ; I'm thirsty' ............... and so forth. “D’you want to ruin me," says the music hall keeper to the same waiter, "serving the beer without any froth ?" It is too muuh ; we cry with Byron :
“Leoncavalllo, you are strong, forbear ;
One more like this were more than we could bear.

But let us do him the justice to say that the music is well on a level with the pervading sentiment of the play ; he is at least consistent. As a performance, admirable ; custom cannot wither Signa. Berlendi's infinite variety (and age for her is still far off) ; from extravagant joy to her bitter despair she holds her audience fast, triumphing in a tiresome part. We were moreover greatly impressed with the respective renderings of Signi. Acerbi and Costa : this for his richness of tone and that for his ease in delivery. Natalia (Signa. Nella Kost) has also a pretty voice, and tiny Miss Finzi ( o we must call her) spoke her little part clearly and attractively. And yet... and yet... one’s insular objections to the sentimentality of very young children on the stage are hard to overcome : tamen noque recurrent.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S Trojan Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester yesterday and is due at Alexandria on or about the 15th inst.
The Florio-Rubattino S.S. Singapore left Messina six-hours behind time and is not expected to reach Alexandria before Sunday evening.

div.head: HELIOPOLIS OASES.
div.p: BUILDING A TOWN.

We promised in a previous issue to give fuller details as to the progress of the work which is being actively pursued in the Abbassieh Oases by the Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Company, and we now propose doing so. In the first place, mention should be made of the work of road making. This has been carried on with marvellous rapidity by the Societe des Travaux Publics of Cairo and Mr. G B. Kerr. In eight months these contractors have constructed magnificent roads extending over ten miles. They inclnde a fine avenue of 40 metres width which traverses the first oasis the whole of its length, and smaller roads of twenty metres width which will be provided with broad pavements. All the roads at present constructed have been macademised with very hard lime-stone, which was partly quarried in the oasis. The important arteries will be served by an electric tramway line for which the company holds the concession, and which will not only run through the two oases and connect them, but will end at Abbassieh, the terminas of the Cairo Tramway Company's line. The work of laying the linè from the oases to Abbassieh has been rapidly progressing, and a large portion of the line has been completed. At present workmen are engaged in putting up the aerial wires. There can be no doubt that the oases will be well connected with Cairo. Trains on the eleotric railway will do the journey from the first oasis to Pont Limoun in 10 minutes, and from the latter station passengers may proceed without changing by the tramway line to the centre of the capital.

The company is having a vast hotel built on its land. This monument—for monument it will be—built to the plans of Architect Jaspar, is in the hands of Messrs. Padova, Rolin aud Co. It is semi circular in shape and has a facade measuring no less than 185 metres. Conceived in the Arab style, its lines are of rare elegance. One cannot but congratulate the architect, whose merits have been more than once recognised in Cairo. The hotel will consist of four floors, three of which have been completed. It will contain five hundred rooms, eacb two rooms having a dressing-room and W.C. ; two restaurants, one on the basement and the other on the first floor, saloons, smoking rooms, reading rooms ; in fact, all that a modern first- class hotel demands.

The construction of the villas, too, is making good headway. Ten villas are at present being built, and the company intends to erect 100 of them, the builders being the Socie e des Travaux Publics, of which Sir Raginald Oakes is also the director general. For these villas the xompany has prepared diffirent types of plans. Some will have one flier only, while others will have two floors. All of them will have a garden both in front and behind, to the S.W. the villas will be protected from the sun by verandahs .These villas will undoubtedly prove very popular, not only with the resident population of Cairo, but with those who come to spend the winter here. Owing to their elevation, 50 to 70 metres above sea level, those oases will be found to be the driest and healthiest spots about Cairo. Add to these natural advantages the reduced rents and comfort of the dwellings, and their popularity cannot be gainsaid.

The company is also constructing a brasserie- restaurant, which has been entrusted to Messrs. Garozzo & Figli. The building will be completed in three mouths’ time. Meantime, Messrs Padova Roliu & Go. are bringing into exist- ence large family hotel which, when finished, will be temporarily occupied by the company’s agents, who will reside there.

Finally, we may mention perhaps one of the most interesting constructions we were privileged to visit, that of the “Garden City," which is almost completed and which is destined to shelter 700 working people, men. women, and children ; which gives one a fair idea of its size. The building consists of two floors. The basement will be occupied by shops of all kinds. The dwellings are of various dimensions and are provided with public lavatories.

Such, after only eight months' work, is the state of advancement of the great project. In the months to come, with the building of new villas, will spring up the administrative buildings, the Catholic church in the centre of the first oasis, the Mohamedan mosque, and all the private buildings on the lauds already sold and those which will be sold in the near future, not forgetting the "Sports Park,” where the ground will be laid out for horse racing, tennis, polo, cricket, etc.

Naturally the foregoing can only give a very bare idea of the company's vast undertaking, and to those who are interested in it we cannot give better advice than that they should go and see for themselves. They will come back with this double impression which we have formed, of the greatness, the beauty, and the great utility of the enterprise, the certainty that not only will it be brought to a successful conclusion, But that it it is likely to meet with enormous success, exceeding the most optimistic hopes.

div.head: SACRILEDGE AT DESHNA.
div.p: A correspondent states that complaints have been to the Coptic Bishop of Keneh by the Coptic priests at Deshneh of the treatment they ave been receiving at the hands if the Moslems. While the priests of El Izah, a village of Deshneh Markaz, were celebratingthe Mass of the sublime Baptism of the Epiphany a band of ghaffirs, headed by the shikh's cousin, made an attack on the church. They broke into the sacred edifice armed with loaded guns and began to mock and jear. They polluted the baptismal font in which was the baptismal water in a most disgusting fashion.

div.head: LUXOR NOTES.
div.p: SEASON IN FULL SWING.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
LUXOR, JANUARY 28.

The season which is perhaps going to mark a new era in Luxor has suddenly rushed into being. Already the new Winter Palace has justified its existence by having filled, to the present extent of its capacities, within a week of its opening, and the remaining rooms are being completed as fast as may be, to meet the demands of booking. Everything is in fall swing, and there is nothing but praise for the comfortable arrangements and ecellence cusine. Weekly dances are to be held in the fine lounge of the hotel, and Signor Bordini's orchestra discourses sweet music afternoon and evening.

Among the visitors now staying here are : Prince Djemil Toussoun and suite, Comte de Bruges and suite, the Bishop of Madras and Mrs. Whitehead, Sir Thomas Wrightson and family, Mr. and Mrs. Pollack von Parnegg, Capt. and Mrs. Devenish and party, Saruf Bey, Col. Beaugarten Crusius and family, M. Achille Fould and party, Lord Halsbury and party. Mr. FitzGerald and party, Comte Delarcochin and party, Mrs. Laidlaw, the Hod. Miss Heneage, Judge Royle, etc.

Sir William and Lady Geary are making the Nile trip and have lately being staying at the Luxor Hotel. He was, until 1897, Attorney General at the Gold Coast, and is author of several important works on legal subjects.
At the Savoy Hotel are to be seen, Dr. H. Goudy, Regius Professor of Civil Law at Oxford, Lady Louisa Maguire, Lady Winifred Corry, Judge Everton, and many others.

The weekly Gymkhanas continue to attract many spectators, to many of whom a race meeting of this kind is quite a novelty. The visitors’ race last week had such large entries that the ladies had a race to themselves, which Miss Ross succeeded in winning, while Baron von Heinzs carried off first prize in the gentlemen's donkey race and the goolah pegging. The race for donkey boys, two on each donkey, back to back caused great amusement. There were about 150 people in the grand stand, a record number for this season, and an unusual crowd of natives lined the other side of the course, making the scene most pcturesque.

A small dance was held at the Winter Palace on Tunsday evening, the first of a weekly series with the management is arranging to hold duriug the season, and which promise to be very popular. Besides the visitors staying in the hotel, many of the passengers on the tourist steamers Rameses and Rameses the Great responded to the invitation of the manner, and all thoroughly appreciated the excellent floor and music which they found awaiting them.

Among the occupants of the dahabeahs now to be seen lining the river side, are Mrs. Rylands (on the Serapis), M. Maspero and party, Mr. Thsodore Davis and party, Mr. Linden Smith and family, and Professor Sayce, who is as snal making Luxor his winter headquarters.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie.)

Le marché est très ferme, quoique peu animé. Les transactions se limitent comme importance aux nouvelles émissions, Agricole, National Bank, Daim, Nungovioh Hotels,Delta Laud, Estatee, Comptoir, Crédit Franco Egyptien et Port Said Salt.

L'Arditi (Bourse and Banking Ci*.)est demandée à 1 13/32 l'aotiou et 25 la part de fon-dateur, la Levioc à l 13/32 l'action et 20 la part de foudateur, l’United à 1 7/32 l’action et 8 7/8 la part de foudateur, les Ri'z Hotels à 1 7 16, et la Lunghis a 1 15/32.
Demande toujours plus active en Agricole, qui clôture acheteurs a 9 7/8, sans vendeurs, On affirme maintenant que le coupon sera au minimum de 8 shellings 6 pence.
Ou ramasse l'Uuion Foncière a 6 1/4. Le bruit court d'une vente avantageuse faite par la société.

En hausse également la National Bank a 23 3/16, la Dai î à 17 3/4, les Lots Turos a 153 la Bai que d’Athenes a 136, la Delta Land a l 9/16, la Nile Land a 19 1/4, l’Investment a 1 11/32, l’action ancienne Comptoir à 7 15/16, l'Anglo Egyptian Allotment k 3 11/16 l’action et 140 la part de fondateur.

Par contre, la Dividende Tramways d'Alexandrie fléchit a 365, la Privilégiée Bière du Caire à 128, la Salt and Soda a 23/3, les Nangovioh Hotels a 23, l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail à 34/6, le Banco di Romaa 115, le Crédit Franco Egyptien à 6 5/16 et la Port Said Salt à 16/9.
Sur le reste auoun changement.
La tendance générale est bonne.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier
div.p: DE
"L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de 1’ "Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de façon a pouvoir ôtre expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marohé des valeurs ; les dernières statistiques jusqu’à la veil e de publication : des, tableaux des fluctuations de là -place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement poor une année en Egypte coûte I L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pou é'tranger 10 P.T. deport en sus.

The Earl and Countess of Carnarvon are due in Cario early this mont. Lord Carnarvon is the fifth Earl and suceeded his father in 1890 Brethby Park, their seat near Burton on Trent, was the seat of the Earls of Chesterfield, but it passed from the possession of the Stanhopes to Lord Carnarvon through his mother, who was the only daughter of the sixth Lord Chesterfield, and sister and heiress of the seventh Earl.

Lady Cooper is shortly coming to Cairo to rejoin Sir Alfred Cooper. She was Lady Agnes Duff, and is a daughter of the 5th Earl of Fife. Sir Alred Cooper is a celebrated F.R.C.S. and late Vice-President of the Royal College of Surgeons, of the Council of which he is a member. He is consulting surgeon to the West London, St. Mark's and the Lock hospitals and was Surgeon Colonel to the Duke of York's Loyal Suffolk Hussars. He was also Surgeon-in Ordinary to the Duke of Saze-Coburg and Gotha (Duke of Edinburgh).

Sir George Doughty, who is on a visit to Egypt, has represented Great Grimsby in Parliament since 1895. He was educated at the Wesleyan Higher Grade School and has twice been Mayor of Grimsby. In the session of 1898 he turned from Liberal to Liberal Unionist and went to his constituents, who, however re-elected him by a majority of some 1,800.

Canon and Mrs. Know Little are staying at the Savoy Hotel. After leaving Trinity College, Cambridge, Canon Knox Little, took the appointment of assistant master at Sherborne School, and he was then appointed Curate of Christ Church, Lancaster. From there he went to Turweston, Bucks, and later to St. Thomas Church in Regent Street, and in 1-75 he became Rector of St. Alban's at Cheetwood, Manchester. He went through the South African war serving first with the Brigade of Guards and subsequently with the Household Cavalry. his writings are many and well-known.

Mr. Felix Cobbold, who is on his way out to Egypt, is Member of Parliament for Ipswich, which seat his father represented from 1847 to 1867. From Eron he went to King's College, Cambridge, or which college he is a senior fellow, and he was called to the Bar at Lincoln's Inn in 1869. From 1885 to 1896 he was M.P. for the Stowmarket Division of Suffolk.
Mr. Robertson, M.P., is leaving to-morrow for England. A farwell banquet is to be given this evening to Mr. Robertson at the Grand Continental Hotel.

Mr. Robertson is due in London on the 8th inst. Mustapha Pasha Kamel's organs tates that when he reaches the Metropolis he will deliver an important speech which he has promised to give to his countrymen.

Judge and Miss Batcheller entertained at dinner on tuesday evening, at their residence in Ramleh, Mr. Justice and Mrs. Brown, of the Supreme Court of the United State, who have been making a trip up the Nile. The other guests greatly appreciated the pleasure of meeting Mr. Justice and Mrs. Brown. Justice Brown has during his thirty years of judicial service participated in forming the jusiprudence of the United States relating to the most importance constitutive and historic questions of the country. Justic Brown visited the Mixed Courts on Wednesday and sat for a while in the Court of Appeal. He and Mrs. Brown left afterwards by the Khedivial Mail steamer for Athens.
Sir Charles and Lady Holled-Smith are shortly expected in Cairo. Sir Charles is coming, we understand, in connectedion with an important scheme or land reclamation.
We regret to report that Senhor Spagnolo, Spanish Consul at Alexandria, at present at Cairo, is seriously ill.
Lieut, the Hon. Caryl D. Baring has resinged his commision in the Coldstream Guards.
The Khedive has conferred the second class of the Osmanieh on Sheikh Mohamed Shaker, president of the Ulema Board of Alexandria.
Captain R.P. Crawley, M.V.O, A.S.C., has been granted four months' leave of absence from March 3.

The Late M. Gabriel Mikael, dragoman of the German Consulate at Cairo, whose funeral took palce on Tuesday, was the son of Hacber Bey Mikaelian, Councillo of the Mixed COurt of Appeal, who the Khedive Ismail commissioned to accompany the late Prince Ibrahim Pasha to Europe. He was grandson of the treasurer of Mohamed Aly, who was a great benefactor of the Armenian Church.
Mr. Perovial has been appointed an engineer in the P.W.D, at a salary of L.E 480 a year.
The salaries of Mr. G Levelbore, ehad inspector and Mr. A. Barsanti, conservator of Cairo Museum, have been increased respectively to L.E. 500 and L.E. 480.
JAPANESE IN CALIFORNIA
SATISFACTIOR SOLUTION OF QUESTION
WASHINGTON, January 31.

President Poosevelt and Messrs. Root and Metcalt discussed the Japanese Californian question with the Calitornian congressmen. The later afterwards stated that they were confident that a satisfactory solution of the question would be reached. They have cabled to the President of the San Francisco Board of Education and the superintendent of schools to come to Washington in order to confer with President Roosevelt and Mr. Root. (Reuter)
WASHINGTON, January 31.
CHURCH AND STATE IN FRANCE.
SCENCE IN THE CHAMBER
PARIS, January 31.

CHAMER OF DEPUTIES-- The Bill abolishing the notification of public meetings, including church services, has been adopted by 550 votes to 5. M. Clemenceau intervened unexpectedly in the course of the debate, and referred to the Bishops' declaration as an isolent ultimatum, but characterised the whole affair as a muddle, whereupon M. Briand indignantly stalked out of the Chamber. M. Clemenceau followed and brought him back. the incident ended harmoniously. (Reuter)
ROYAL VISIT TO PARIS
LONDON, January 31.
The King and Queen are going to Paris on Saturday for a short stay prior to the opening of Parliament. The King will stay at the Embassy and the Queen at Lady De Grey's house. (Reuter)
PARIS, January 31.
The King and Queen of England will arrive here on Satuday, and will remain incognito for a week. (Havas)
MR.LONG, M.P. AND HOME RULE
LONDON, January 31

Mr. Walter Long, speaking at Belfast, where he ahs been elected Chairman of the Ulster fighting the new sapping and (under)mining policy of Home Rule from an Imperial stand-point, because Home Rule, he said, would mean the removal of the most important corner-stone of the Empire. (Reuter)
SPREAD OF CEREBRAL MENINGITIS
GLASGOW, January 31
There are 33 cases of cerebral meningitis here, 17 of which have already turned fatal. Several deaths have occurred at Leith. (R.)
DERBYSHIRE BYE-ELECTION
LONDON, January 31
Derbyshire, Bye-election. Mr. Harey, the Laboyr candidate, was elected with 6,644 votes in place of Mr. Bolton, Liberal, deceased. Mr. Court, the Unionist candidate, had 5,915 votes. (Reuter)
AMERICAN COLLIERY EXPLOSION
NEW YORK, January 31
Four bodies have been recovered at the Faretteville collivery. It is believed that all the entombed men are dead. (Reuter)
HUNGARIAN MINISTER RESIGNS
BUDAPEST, January 31
M. Polonyi, Minister of Justice, has resigned with the object of prosectuing his calumniators. (Havas)
PROMOTION FOR M.ALTERMER
PARIS, January 31
M. Altemer has been promoted to the second of his grade. (Havas)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: (FROM OUT FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENTS.)
London, January 25
The Money Market.

Sir Felix Schuster's well-considered remarks on the monetary position, and his prediction that, as far as this country is conserned, there seems no reason to anticipate much lower rates for money daring the next few months, but that, unless unforeseen contingencies should arise, the balance of the flow of gold will be inward rather than outward, are in accordance with the views of almost all the best financial authorities. In view of the probable large redemption of debt by the Government, the more peaceful outlook in international politics, and the general activity of trade in the country, he considers there is justification for taking a hopeful view of the future, and for looking forward to a period of continued prosperity and easier conditions in the money market, though not in the immediate future.

The Bank statement this week lends support to this optimistic view of the situation. The reserve has been further increased to the extent of £1,612,000, thanks to the continued reflux of currency from the country, the total reserve now being £24,205,000 which is about £1,750,000 higher than at this period last year. The proportion to liabilities is now 6 3/8 per cent higher than twelve months ago, being 48 7/8 as against 42 1/2. Coin to the amount of £1,788,000 has returned from internal circulation, so that allowing for the net afflux of £350,000 to other countries, the stook of ballton at the Bank has been increased by £1,438,010 The active note circulation has contracted by £178,000. Public deposits are £2,931,000 higher, but "Other" securities show a decline of £l,985,000, and there is consequently a reduction of £3,330,000 in market balances.
There is a good demand for money. The Bank has done a small business in loans at 5 ½ per cent. Discount rates are about 4 5/8 to 4 ¾ for three months' bills.
The Stock Markets.

The unexpected dulness of the markets since the reduction of the Bank rate is now explained by the news that during the last few weeks a firm of unquestioned credit, who had been too largely committed in option speculations, has been liquidating on a very large scale. No farther unpleasant consequences are now anticipated, and the result will probably be in ths end productive of a considerably better feeling. We believe that there productive extend not only to a large mass of American railroad securities, but also to South African mining shares. The resultant evil has been already borne without serious trouble, and an ngly cloud has disappeared from the horizon.

Naturally, the operations referred to above have kept new business at a very low ebb throughout the week, the situation being each as to cause the more favourable factors, such as easier money and good railway dividend announcments,to be more or less ignored.
To day's business continues almost at a stand still, there being a complete absence of public interest.
Consols.

Gilt-edged securities have been quiet through-out, and the reduction of the German Bank rate had little effect upon movements. The excellent Bank return yesterday has now given a little strength to the market, and Consols have improved to 87 for cash and 87 1/16 for the account.
Foreign Bonds.

The international market is quiet. There has again been a good demand for Japanese stocks, presumably in anticipation of the early conversion of the six per cent loans. Yesterday the Second Series Sixes advanced 3/8 to 102 ½, and several other issues were 1/8 better. The stocks have received some little support to-day.
Russians were good early in the week, but they are now inclined to be dull. The Fours are quoted 77 ¾ and the New Fives 3 ¼ discount.
Home Rails.

The prominent feature of the home railway section has been the dividend announcements. For the most part those are regarded as satisfactory though it is felt that in two or three instances the amount of the declaration is disapproving in view of the big increases in profits which have been made during the half year.

The Great Eastern dividend is at the rate of 5 per cent per annum, with a carry-forward of £88,280 against a balance of £88,746 carried forward in the corresponding half of 1905. The Lancashire and York hire recommend a distribution at the rate of 1 ¾ perr cent with £32, 300 forward, as compared with 4 1/4 in the corresponding period of last year and a forward balance of £31,700. The South Eastern and Chatham maintains its rate of 4 ½ per cent, on the undivided Ordinary, giving £4 10 actual to the Preferred, so that with the interim dividend for the whole of 1906 the undivided get £215 against £2.10 for 1905, and the Preferred £5.10 against £5. There is, however, decline of £7,500 in the carry forward.

The London, Chatham, and Dover again declares £2.5 per cent, and the forward balance reduced by £1,600. The North Staffordshire are able to recommend a dividend of 4 3/4 per cent, an increase of 1/2 per cent, and the balance forward is increased from £7,847 to £10,465.

The Great Central balance dividend at the rate of 6 per cent, per annum on the 1889 four per cent. Preference stock (making the fall per cent, for the year) compares with one at the rate of 6 ¼ per cent, (actually 3 1/6 per cent for the twelve-month) while the 1891 stock gets 1/2 per cent, the last previous payment
on this stock having been mads eight years ago. The balance forward is slightly smaller at about £7,500 compared with £8,282.
The North Eastern directors have to-day declared a dividend at the rate of 7 per cent., carrying forward £82,800. A year ago the distribution was at the rate of 6 1/4 per cent, with £49,000 forward.

Home railway shares have been dull and dealings very restricted. The North Staffordshire dividend announcement was very favourably received, the Ordinary shares gaining no more than 3 1/2 to 103 1/2. South Eastern and Chatham and Lancashire and Yorkshire also showed slight gains on balance. Brighton and Great Eastern fell back somewhat, but in the main the changes were small.
To-day home railways have been weak, but North Eastern are exceptionally firm on the dividend.
Americans.

The American railway market has kept steady, considering the liquidation in some of the stocks to which we have already referred. yesterday prices were well above parity at the opening, and although there was not very much during closing quotations showed appreciable improvements in several directions, Union Pacific gaining 1 ¼ Southern Pacific 1, and Chicago-Milwaukee 1.
Canadian Pacific have been a very weak point, owing to extensive sales of the stock. Yesterday the price declines as low as 190 3/8. At the last makeup they were quoted 197 ½.
Americans are irregular to-day, and movements are generally adverse. Southern Preference have been an exception, and close 2 higher.
Egyptians.

Corporation of Western Egypt have again proved the chief centre of interest in the Egyptian market. After being neglected in consequence of the new issue, the old shares have again received attention, both new and old issues having been well dealt in. The old shares have improved to 1 1/8, and the new, after changing hands at 1/16 discount, have been brought up to 1/16 premium. They close firm at par.

Egyptian Estates have been offered down to 2 2/16, and the Deferred close at 21-23, but there is no business doing in these shares, United Egyptian LAnds are about ¼ premium, and the Deferred 9-10. National Bank of Egypt are easier at 28 3/8, and Agricultural Bank at 9 5/8. Agricultural Bank 3 ½ per cent bonds are 89 -90

Daria Sanieh are again down to 17 ½, but the Deferred are unchanged a 98 100 nominal. Delta Preference are distinctively off and have been dealt in at 11 ½, but close at 11 5/8. Delta Land and Investment are quite a nominal market at 4 3/8 5/8.

Egyptian Markets have been enquired about, and a few hundred shares have fetched 32s. today. Salt & Soda are 1 1/8 Land Bank are firmer at 9 ¼, but Union Fonciere are easier at 6 ¼. Khedivial Mail are unchanged at 1 13/16, as are also Bank of Roumania at 9 ½.
Mining.

Very little new business has been transacted in the South African mining market this week. A few specialities have received attention, but for the most part shares have ben inactive. Yesterday, Paris was a small buyer of Kaffirs. The relapse in prices is attributed to the realisations on behalf of the firm mentioned above. On balance, however, the declines in Kaffirs were only slight.
Today Kaffirs have been weak Rand Mines leave off 7 1/16 and East Rands at 4 11/16.

In the Egyptian mining section, Nile Valleys have continued erratic. After recovering to 5/6, they gave way 3d, yesterday. They close to-night at 5/6. Egyptian Mines, which also hose 3d. yesterday, leave off at 4s. There are no other changes to record.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, January 24.
There is no improvement in the demand for Egyptians on the spot; prices are somewhat irregular bu without change in quotations. In Futures a moderate business has been done.

table.head: The following are the latest values: --

div.p: American Futures.–– The market this week has been quiet and featureless, with constant small fluctuations. To-day's closing values are 2 ½ @ ½ points for old crop, and 1 @ 1 ½ points higher for new crop positions, than those of last Thursday.

There is an entire absence of speculative interest at the moment, but the continuance of excellent trade conditions from all the industrial centres has mantained prices, in face of continued heavy crop movements and American "bear" manipulation. The Ginners report issued steady gives the amount ginned to the 16 harvest. as 12,167,000 bales, against 12,755,00 in the big crop year (1904-1905). This we consider does not indiate a yieled exceeding 13 millions, taking into account the gerneally accepted view that the crop has been moved with unusual rapidity, owing to the enormus contracts entered into before the season opened, the high rate of money prevailing, and the good prices obtained by planters.
The latest quotations are, delivery:
January 5.56d. Mar/Apl. 5.49 June/July 3.47d.
Sept./Oct. 5d.36 ½.
Jan/Feb. 5.55 Apl/May 5.48 ½ July.Aug. 5.4 ½
Oct./Nov. 5.32d.
Feb./Mar. 5.51 May/June 5.47 ½ Aug./Sep. 5.40 1/2
Nov./Dec 5.31 ½.
KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
3rd WINTER MEETING

A handsome cup has been presented by Mr. E.C Hogg for a handicap for English horses Class I. The race will be called the "Velocity Cup" and will be run on the 22nd February at the second day's racing of the 3rd Winter Meeting. The entrance money (2) will go to the second house. Entries close on 15th February.

Mr. E. C. Hoog is a sportmas of the right sort and well-known to all of us. What he does not known about racing is not worth knowing. His sporting gift will doubtless do a great deal towards encouraging races for English horses in Egypt.
POLO.
Owing to the temporary absence of several leading players, the Open Cup advertised for the 12th February has been postponed, and the programmed revised. The tournament will be played as follows:
5th Feb. to 12th Feb. Ladies Nominations.
Feb. 15.–– Subalterns' Cup
9this Cup has been presented by the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards to be won three times by same regiment),
Feb 23.–– The macgilocrag Cup,
(Classification Tournament).
March 1. ––Open Cup,
March 8––Gordon Cup.
TENNIS.

div.head: FEEDING OF CHILDREN.
div.p: Tbe most important question for every mother to decide is "How shall I feed my baby? " Of course, if possible, the answer to this question should be breast feeding, for that is nature’s own arrangement for both mother and child; yet there are many cases in which it is impossible or, at any rate, inadvisable for a mother to nurse her infant. In these cases hand feeding must be resorted to, and no better food for the purpose can be had Neave’s Food, which has 80 years’ established reputation and is testified to by leading mecial men and by the medical press generally. Among other advantages which it possesses are that it is quckily and easily made, it assists teething, it is strength-giving and flesh and bone-forming. The food was awarded Gold Medals in London in 1900 and 1906. All interested should read "Hints about Baby, by a Trained Nurse," which may be had of Messrs. J. R. Neave & Co., Fordingbridge, England.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There will be two appointments for Doctors in the Sudan Medical Department made about April next.
Candidates should foward all t estimonials to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.
Information as to age, qualifications, engagments since qualifications, is required.
Candidates should be about 25 years old and unmarried, and should have a good knowledge of English and Arabic. Egyptians will be preferred.
Salary to commence at the rate of L.E. 20 er mensem, eligible for increase after two years' satisfactory service.
Applicants should be prepared to appear for interview about the 2nd week in March 1907, in Cairo.
Appointment for probation 3 months, afterwards for a year before being permanently admitted inot the Government service.
Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo.
ALexandria, January 17,1907.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Commission Municipale s’ust réunite le 30 janvier 1907 a 4 h. 1/2 p.m. sons la présidence de S E. le Dr. Schiess pacha.

Présents: MM. Ahmed pacha Yehia, Ahmed bey Eyoub, J. Barbaza, E. Benachi, L Escoffier, P. Fenderl, E.W.P. Foster, H. P. Kingham, Mansourr bey Yonssef, baron A. de Menasce, Mohamed bey Mahtouz, A. Padoa bey, Amb. A. Ralli, D. Rieti, O Rothacker, M. Salvago, E. Stroas, Soliman bey Abani, D. Tambaco poule, G. Zervudachi, membres,W.P.Chataway, administrateur, 1. Sedky bey, secrétaire général.
Les procès-verbaux de la Commission des 5 et 19 décembre 1907 sont adoptés.
Mention est faite de l’envoi a tons les men bras des procès verbaux de la Délégation des 24, 27 novembre, 3, 4, 15, 18 décembre 1906 et 9 janvier 1907.
Communication est donnée des lettres vantes dn Ministère de l’intérienr :
1. une lettre du 5 janvier 1907 approuvant le budget arrêté par la Commission dans sa séance du 26 décembre 1906.
2. Une lettre dn 7 janvier 1907 approuvant les divers virements de crédits poor régularisation du comptes de fin d'année, votés par la Commission dans sa séauce du 26 décembre 1906.
3. Une lettre dn 7 janvier 1907, apponvant les divers crédits votés par la Commission à la même séance.

La Commission preud également connaissance d’ane lettre du 22 janvier 1907 da "Ministère de l'Intérieur informant, en réponse à lavis de vente des terrains des quais qui lui a été commnniqué, que le Miuistère des Finances n’a pas d’objection a ce qu’il soit procédé à la vente des lots Nos. X XX111, 11, XV, ainsi que des parties Nos. 1, 2, 3, du lot No. XXI, No 2 du lot No. XXV et No. 1, 2, du lot No. XXXIV.

Quant aux parties- N 4 5.6 du lot N. XX0.1, 3, 4. du lot N. XXV et 3, 4 du lot N. XXXIV, le Ministre duse Finances dit quèlles appartiennent tout au moins eu partie, au gouvernement, et qu’il juge en conséquence utile ds les exclure de l’avis de publication de misa en vente.

Après on échange d'idées, considérant que la ligne de démarcation établie d'accord avec le représentant du Gouvernement et séparant les terrains conquis sur la mer de ceux formant l' ancien rivage, indique bien, ainsi quil résulte d’antre part des explications fournies par l'Administrateur et le Président du Comité des Travaux Publics, que les terrains conteatés sont de ceux conquis sur la mer, la Commission, sur la proposition de M. Foster, amendée par Padoa bey, décide de donne- suite à la vente des lots en question, sauf rè glement éventuel du prix.

M.de Menasce fait remarquer que le compte reniu communiqué au Ministère des doux dernières séances pas plus que celui de la presse ne contient ses observations ni sa protestation au sujat du chapitre du budget relatif aux allocations, de telle sorte que le Ministere en approuvant le budget, n’a pn en prendre connaissane et ne les saura que lors de l’envoi da procès verbal définitif a montent cù il serait trop tard pour revenir sur une approbation déja donnée.
Il demande qu’a l’avenir le Ministère soit mis-en mesure de connstcre en temps utile les objection que des membres peuvent avoir sur certaines décisions.
Il en est pris note.
La Commission prend connaissauoe do rap-port préliminaire sur les comptes de l’année 1906 et adopte l’état des credits reportés en 1907 pour les depenses engages et non reglees en 1906.
L’assemblée approuve, vn la recrudescence de l’épidémie de la morve, un arrêté tendant a la fermeture, jasqu’a nouvel ordre, de tous les abreuvoirs publics dans la ville d’Alexandrie et sa banlieue.

A cette occasion et sur l’observation de M. Benachi, il est décidé d’écrire a la police d’empêchar les cultivateurs qui importent le ber sim en ville, de l’asperger avec de l’eau des mares stagnantes, cette opération étant une des causes principales de contamination.

La Commission aborde la question des terrains revendiqués par l’Etat près de la gaie de Ramleh, à laquelle se lie une proposition du Comité des Travaux publics relative à la mise en location d’une superficie équivalant an double de ces terrains, dont l’Etat ferait l’abandon.

Après une longue disensssion et sur la proposition de Yehia pacha, la Commission décide de renvoyer an Comité du Contentieux l'examen de la question des droits que peut avoir la Municipalité sur les terrains revendiqués et au Comité des Finances celui de la qnestion de la location des terrains,
La Comm ssion de l’avis conforme de la Délégation, décide l'ouverture des crédits suivants:

list.item: L.E. 60 a prélever sur le budget extraordinaire ponr la publication du nouveau guide du Musée.

L.E. 560 à prélever sur le budget extraordinaire, pour l’installation de bouches à incendie, sauf examen par le Comité da Contentieux sur le point de savoir si cette dépense ne devrait pas incomber à la Compagnie des Eaux.
L.E. 300, a prelever sur le budget ordinaire, pour l'organisation de concerts de musique publics.
L.E. 1640, a prelever sur le budget extraordinare pour le redressment et la canalisation de la rue Imam Aly.
L.E. 450 pour la construction de deuz salles au Musee, a prelever sur le budget extraordinarie.
L.E. 500 pour le Musee, dont L.E. 400 pour fouilles et L.E. 100 pour peinture des salles, a prelver sur le budget extrordinare.
L.E. 300 pour la vacciation a prelever sur la revere du budget ordinaire.

div.p: 8. L.E. 260, à prélever sur le budget extra ordinaire pour la peinture de la grille et la réparation des canaux d’irrigation et da mur de soubassement du grand jardin Nouzha.

La Commission ajourne l’examen de la demande de credit pour la construction une galerie pour le legs Friedheim, eu vue de pouvoir étudier cette question en meme temps que celle de la construction d’un nouveau palais municipal.
La séanoe est levée à 7 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUE
Le Caire, Jeudi 31 Janvier.

Le taux de l’escompte Mbre a Londres a flechi hier de 1/8 à 4 3/4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé de 1/8 à 87 1/8 et l' Unifiee de 1 4 à 102 3/4 La National Bark est restée invariée à 28 1/4 la Daïra à 17 1/2 et la Delta Light à 1/2. L’Agricole a avancé de 1/8 à 9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Funnier est resté à 777. La Banque d’Athèues a rétrogradé de 1 franc à 137.

Ici, le marché a é é. ce matin, calme mais soutenu au début de la séance. IKy a ensuite une certaine animation avec bonne tendance, qui s’est manifestée specialement sur la National Bank, l'Agricole, la Delta Land, 1es Nungovieh, les Baehler et les Estates. Aussi bien on s’attend a one reprise générale dès que le cup de la liquidation aura été double a Alexandrie après le Caire.
Daus le compartiment des Banques la National a avancé à 28 3/16 1/4 et l’Agricole a 9 7/8. La Cassa di Scoute s’est alourdie à 284. Le Comptoir Financier s’est raffermi à 7 7/8
Le Crédit Foncier, dont l’assemblée générale ordinaire a lieu cst après midi, gressé à 778. La Nile Land a atteint 19.

L’Allotment a passé de 3 1/2 a 3 5/8 11/16; on a prétendu en Bourse qu’il exsterait un découvert sur ce titre; nous n’avons pas en le temps de contôler la véracité de cette ru meur. La part de fondateur est ramonée a 142.

Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont été cotées 15 1/2-16; leur part a clôture à 342. L’Epargne Immobilière a avancé a 3 11/16; sa part affui a 292. L'Express Nile a ete ramene a 5 1/8 et sa part a 300.
La Delta Light a faibli à 11 9/16. Les Jouissances Eaux dn Caire ont gagné 6 franos 297. Les Automobiles sont remontées à 5 3/4 l8 16.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ent avancé a 23 1/16 sur la ru-meur d’une vente de terrain, et les Egyptian a 12 3/4-13/16. Les Excelsior ont fléchi 4 7/16.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land eu très bonne teuus, a clôturé a 4 7 16, ache teurs. Las Estates se sont raffermis à 2 5/8 leur part a haussé à 22 7/8 23,
Rien de particulier à relever sur les autres tires. La part Bourse du Caire a ete inscribe a 75 sur la cote officielle se la Corportaion au lieu de 80.

On annonce d’Alexandrie que l’émission de 100,000 actions ordinaires nouvelles à £ 1 de la Kbelivial Mail Steamship Co. aura lian dans la seconde quinzaine de Février. Le prix d'émission a été fixé à £ 1.7.6. Les détenteurs d actions anciennes auront 1e droit de sonscrire dans la proportion de 71 actions nouvelles ponr 100 anciennes, soit privilégiés, soit ordinaires. La somme de 7 sh. 6 sera payable à la souscription et le solde à la répartition aux benefices de l’exarclce en cours à partir de la date de la répartition.

Les rumeurs répandues ces jours derniers, au Caire et à Alexandrie, au suhst d’une fusion entre la Salt and Soda et la Port-Said Salt Association n'etaient pas, paralt, exactes. Le mouvement qui s’est produit en Bouise sur les deux titres devrait être simplement attribué a une entente intervonue entre ces Sociétés en vue d éliminer dans la vente du sel rine concurrence qui pourrait être préjudiciable aux deux parties.

On rapporte que l'Egyptian Markets Ltd. v prochainement émettre le solde de son capital autorisé, soit £ 50,000 en actions de £1. L’émission aurait lien à 27 sh. 6. Les détenteurs d’actions anciennes auraient, à la souscription, droit à 2 actions nouvelles pour 5 anciennes.

Cette émission serait motivée, semble-t-il, par la conoes ion que la Société aurait, obtenue, à certaines conditions, de l’Etat d’avoir le monopole de l'importation en Egypte des engrais de nitrate, dont la demande devient de plus en plus considérable pour les besoins de l’agriculture.
an lien de 80.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
